summary:
Person B was sat in class, headphones in, waiting for class to start.
Person A walked in and decided to finally make a move.
It...
body:
Person B was sat in class, headphones in, waiting for class to start.

Person A walked in and decided to finally make a move.

It was about halfway through the quarter and A felt they cracked B’s walls enough to finally ask them on a date.

They zoomed over, plopped down in the seat next to B and took out their earbud.

A had planned this eloquent and elaborate asking out, but totally flubbed it up and ended up just muttering out gibberish relating to “you, me, out, dinner?”

B rolled their eyes, but had a small smile on their face and responded that it didn’t sound like a horrible idea, but A has to pay for it.

A lit up and exclaimed that’s totally fine as long as they are together, while B quietly sat there watching A with a smile.

EXTRA:

They had an awkward date, what with neither of them having real experience on a date before but had a good time with each other.

blog.title: Yo I Comment On The Drama When Shit Hits The Fan
blog.description:
Phandom drama? It's more likely than you think.

.

My ask box is always open if you need a place to be dramatic, share theories, conspiracies, opinions, or general grievances. Fire away, my babies. Nothing is off limits. (Except for the things that are.)

Icon by phanniephobic, header by cinnamonnutlester

summary: I know I’m a little late to this particular discourse, but here goes: I feel like those who are worried about Dan stepping away...
question: I know I’m a little late to this particular discourse, but here goes: I feel like those who are worried about Dan stepping away from being a capital-Y Youtuber should really try to keep in mind that it was never really his plan to be one in the first place. It seems like some of his younger fans don’t quite realize that, and that’s honestly not their fault, because they may not have even been around to witness what Youtube was like at the time that Dan started. (1/7)
answer:
“It was nowhere near the kind of platform that it was today. It was something that people did for fun, and being a career Youtuber wasn’t a big Thing. Hell, when Phil started Youtube, making it a career wasn’t even an option. I think the case for both of them, but for Dan especially, is that Youtube was a fun thing that they started doing at very young ages, and they ended up finding a lot of unexpected success. (2/7)”


“And like, when you’re very young and you find that you can make a good living out of doing something that started off as just a hobby for you, then hell yeah you’re gonna capitalize on it without necessarily thinking about its long-term implications. Again, this applies especially to Dan, because his crescendo of internet fame happened at a time when he had absolutely no idea what he wanted to do with his life. (3/7)”


“He’d dropped out of college (or university I guess but I’m American lol) and had no direction. And he was able to find a lot of success in a booming new industry, and build a successful brand both on his own and with his best friend, and that’s great. But this is kind of a pivotal moment in his life. Youtube is a big business now, and Dan’s in his late 20s, and it’s like… does he want Youtube to be his Job for the rest of his life? (4/7)”


“Does he want to use his Youtube success as a stepping stone into some other creative/entertainment industry? Does he want to abandon the platform altogether and take his life in a completely different direction? Does he want to have some sense of like, “traditional normalcy” that his Youtube career and branding doesn’t really offer? (5/7)”


“Who knows, but it must be getting more and more complicated for him as he gets older, considering that he had no way of planning for his future while his internet success was happening (because he was among the first wave of people to become Really Successful on social media, so there was honestly no telling what the future would hold). This is becoming a very long-winded stream-of-consciousness clusterfuck, so I think I’ll just end it here. (6/7)”


“TL;DR, Dan never planned on being internet famous, and while he’s clearly very grateful for his fans and his success and his relationship (whatever it may be) with Phil and proud of all he’s been able to do, he may not want to do it forever. Whether he decides to stay on Youtube, continues but just to a lesser extent, leaves altogether, or whatever, I’ll be happy for him. He brought me a lot of joy during some of my very difficult formative years, and I’ll be grateful for that regardless. (7/7)”


.

.

.


You know, I think 7 parts is the longest ask I’ve gotten to date. Well done, anon.


I really don’t have much to add. I don’t really disagree with a single thing you said. A lot of the old-school youtubers never intended to be famous at all. 10 years ago, youtube was more of a hobby you had the option to get paid for. So like you said, of course people jumped at the opportunity to make a bit of extra cash doing stuff they were already doing anyway.


Then it reached a point where you could make more money on YouTube than you did at your day job. So people jumped on the opportunity to pursue youtube full time.


Now it’s changing again. There’s not as much freedom for creators now. With “the algorithm” fucking everyone over, with Adsense in the toilet, it’s become a competition of views and likes and who has the most subscribers and who gets the best brand deals and who sells the most merch. It really is a business now, and youtube rewards the people who treat it like a business.


It seems like Dan and Phil tried to keep up with it for a while. They wrote a book when youtubers writing books was a big thing. They went on tour when youtubers going on tour was a big thing. But somewhere post-tatinof seems to be where their channels started declining and I think at least Dan, is finally throwing in the towel. Not necessarily because he cares about the views, but because youtube has changed into something so different that he just seems kind of done with it.


And who knows what he’ll do next. Maybe he’ll get a “real job”. Maybe he’ll throw himself into his thing with young minds. Maybe he’ll just flat out retire, since he’s most likely rich enough to do so.


But I really don’t think we’ll see him drop entirely off the platform. I think he still enjoys making videos. He’s said himself that he considers himself an entertainer, a content creator. So I think he’s gonna keep making content. I just don’t think he gives a fuck how many people are watching. Because he knows someone is watching. I think he’ll make videos whenever he wants to make them, and he won’t worry about whether or not youtube and “the algorithm” are going to reward him for it.


As for Phil, he doesn’t seem to be going down that road quite yet. But I think you’ll see him follow before too long.

So I think he’s gonna keep making content. I just don’t think he gives a fuck how many people are watching. Because he knows someone is watching. I think he’ll make videos whenever he wants to make them, and he won’t worry about whether or not youtube and “the algorithm” are going to reward him for it.


As for Phil, he doesn’t seem to be going down that road quite yet. But I think you’ll see him follow before too long.
trail.content:
“It was nowhere near the kind of platform that it was today. It was something that people did for fun, and being a career Youtuber wasn’t a big Thing. Hell, when Phil started Youtube, making it a career wasn’t even an option. I think the case for both of them, but for Dan especially, is that Youtube was a fun thing that they started doing at very young ages, and they ended up finding a lot of unexpected success. (2/7)”


“And like, when you’re very young and you find that you can make a good living out of doing something that started off as just a hobby for you, then hell yeah you’re gonna capitalize on it without necessarily thinking about its long-term implications. Again, this applies especially to Dan, because his crescendo of internet fame happened at a time when he had absolutely no idea what he wanted to do with his life. (3/7)”


“He’d dropped out of college (or university I guess but I’m American lol) and had no direction. And he was able to find a lot of success in a booming new industry, and build a successful brand both on his own and with his best friend, and that’s great. But this is kind of a pivotal moment in his life. Youtube is a big business now, and Dan’s in his late 20s, and it’s like… does he want Youtube to be his Job for the rest of his life? (4/7)”


“Does he want to use his Youtube success as a stepping stone into some other creative/entertainment industry? Does he want to abandon the platform altogether and take his life in a completely different direction? Does he want to have some sense of like, “traditional normalcy” that his Youtube career and branding doesn’t really offer? (5/7)”


“Who knows, but it must be getting more and more complicated for him as he gets older, considering that he had no way of planning for his future while his internet success was happening (because he was among the first wave of people to become Really Successful on social media, so there was honestly no telling what the future would hold). This is becoming a very long-winded stream-of-consciousness clusterfuck, so I think I’ll just end it here. (6/7)”


“TL;DR, Dan never planned on being internet famous, and while he’s clearly very grateful for his fans and his success and his relationship (whatever it may be) with Phil and proud of all he’s been able to do, he may not want to do it forever. Whether he decides to stay on Youtube, continues but just to a lesser extent, leaves altogether, or whatever, I’ll be happy for him. He brought me a lot of joy during some of my very difficult formative years, and I’ll be grateful for that regardless. (7/7)”


.

.

.


You know, I think 7 parts is the longest ask I’ve gotten to date. Well done, anon.


I really don’t have much to add. I don’t really disagree with a single thing you said. A lot of the old-school youtubers never intended to be famous at all. 10 years ago, youtube was more of a hobby you had the option to get paid for. So like you said, of course people jumped at the opportunity to make a bit of extra cash doing stuff they were already doing anyway.


Then it reached a point where you could make more money on YouTube than you did at your day job. So people jumped on the opportunity to pursue youtube full time.


Now it’s changing again. There’s not as much freedom for creators now. With “the algorithm” fucking everyone over, with Adsense in the toilet, it’s become a competition of views and likes and who has the most subscribers and who gets the best brand deals and who sells the most merch. It really is a business now, and youtube rewards the people who treat it like a business.


It seems like Dan and Phil tried to keep up with it for a while. They wrote a book when youtubers writing books was a big thing. They went on tour when youtubers going on tour was a big thing. But somewhere post-tatinof seems to be where their channels started declining and I think at least Dan, is finally throwing in the towel. Not necessarily because he cares about the views, but because youtube has changed into something so different that he just seems kind of done with it.


And who knows what he’ll do next. Maybe he’ll get a “real job”. Maybe he’ll throw himself into his thing with young minds. Maybe he’ll just flat out retire, since he’s most likely rich enough to do so.


But I really don’t think we’ll see him drop entirely off the platform. I think he still enjoys making videos. He’s said himself that he considers himself an entertainer, a content creator. So I think he’s gonna keep making content. I just don’t think he gives a fuck how many people are watching. Because he knows someone is watching. I think he’ll make videos whenever he wants to make them, and he won’t worry about whether or not youtube and “the algorithm” are going to reward him for it.


As for Phil, he doesn’t seem to be going down that road quite yet. But I think you’ll see him follow before too long.
